displaytitle: Vessel in the form of a feline
medium: Ceramic with kaolin slip and red slip-paint with resist-applied black colorant
creditline: Museum purchase, Fowler McCormick, Class of 1921, Fund

titles.title: Vessel in the form of a feline

texts.textentryhtml: The Recuay culture of the northern Peruvian highlands normally limited the colors of their slipped pottery to cream, red or orange, and black. As is typical for the style, this figural vessel incorporates a resist technique, whereby a plant resin was applied to certain areas after it was slipped white. Black slip was then painted over these designs; when the vessel was fired, the resin burned away, preserving the white and producing negative designs. This vessel portrays an animal: while the bodily proportions seem akin to a llama, the presence of fangs and comparison to other Recuay works of art suggest that a feline may have been intended. Alternatively, the work might represent a composite creature.

After 1968 but before July, 1970, Benno Mattel (1917-2017), Buenos Aires, Argentina and, Montevideo, Uruguay [1]; sold to David Bernstein Fine Art, New York; 2010, sold to private collection, New York [2]; 2024, sold to Princeton University Art Museum.

Notes:
[1] The presence of the work in the Mattel collection between 1968 and 1970 is based on photographic evidence. Justin Kerr photographed highlights of the Mattel collection in 1968 but did not include this object, while photographs of the Mattel collection date-stamped July 1970 taken by David Bernstein illustrate this work. Copies in the curatorial file.
[2] According to private collection.

geography.displaygeography: Place made: South America, Peru, Ancash, Central highlands, Callejón de Huaylas

caption: Recuay, Early Intermediate Period (Recuay phase, Recuay II subphase), 200–600 CE, Ancash, Central highlands, Peru, Andes, Vessel in the form of a feline. Ceramic with kaolin slip and red slip-paint with resist-applied black colorant; 26 × 25.4 × 10.2 cm. Museum purchase, Fowler McCormick, Class of 1921, Fund (2023-27)
